articles.headline: China Presses Its Internet Censorship Efforts Across the Globe
articles.snippet: Beijing is pushing past its digital borders to influence and control what people say online, as it enjoys growing sway in the technology world.
articles.abstract: Beijing is pushing past its digital borders to influence and control what people say online, as it enjoys growing sway in the technology world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Within its digital borders, China has long censored what its people read and say online. Now, it is increasingly going beyond its own online realms to police what people and companies are saying about it all over the world.

articles.headline: Anatomy of a School Lockdown: A Threat, Then the Anxious Wait
articles.snippet: Schools have seen more threats and false alarms since the recent shooting in Parkland, Fla. “We can no longer say, ‘Aww, he didn’t mean it,’” an Illinois officer says.
articles.abstract: Schools have seen more threats and false alarms since the recent shooting in Parkland, Fla. “We can no longer say, ‘Aww, he didn’t mean it,’” an Illinois officer says.
articles.lead_paragraph: FULTON, Ill. — Chris Tennyson, the principal of Fulton High School, was winding his way through the school hallway just before lunch on Tuesday when a female student stopped him, worry etched on her face.

articles.headline: China’s Biggest Deal Maker Spent Billions. Now the Bill Comes Due.
articles.snippet: As Beijing puts growing pressure on some of the country’s most ambitious companies, HNA rushes to sell assets to help pay back $90 billion in debt.
articles.abstract: As Beijing puts growing pressure on some of the country’s most ambitious companies, HNA rushes to sell assets to help pay back $90 billion in debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stephen Schwarzman, the Wall Street rainmaker, took the stage at a black-tie gala in Manhattan in January to present an award to a Chinese corporate behemoth that has become a major player in global deal making.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Why Italy’s Insular Election Is More Important Than It Looks
articles.snippet: Before Sunday’s vote, Italy’s campaign, self-obsessed as it has been, brought into focus the political forces that portend badly for the European Union.
articles.abstract: Before Sunday’s vote, Italy’s campaign, self-obsessed as it has been, brought into focus the political forces that portend badly for the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — The campaign before Italy’s national elections on Sunday has been self-obsessed and often petty and unedifying. But it has been instructive about one thing: The political forces that have torn at the global order and the European Union have settled into the mainstream.

articles.headline: Trump’s Steel Tariffs Raise Fears of a Damaging Trade War
articles.snippet: A global tit-for-tat on trade could crimp economic growth, undermining the stimulative effects of President Trump’s deregulation push and his signature $1.5 trillion tax cut.
articles.abstract: A global tit-for-tat on trade could crimp economic growth, undermining the stimulative effects of President Trump’s deregulation push and his signature $1.5 trillion tax cut.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After making good on tax cuts and regulatory rollbacks that business leaders wanted, President Trump has turned to a part of his economic agenda that many of them feared: tariffs.

articles.headline: Trump’s Tariffs Prompt Global Threats of Retaliation
articles.snippet: In Canada, Europe and Asia, leaders said they would respond to Mr. Trump’s steel and aluminum tariffs with restrictions of their own.
articles.abstract: In Canada, Europe and Asia, leaders said they would respond to Mr. Trump’s steel and aluminum tariffs with restrictions of their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A day after President Trump took a swing at United States trading partners by threatening stiff and sweeping tariffs on steel and aluminum, they hit back. They promised to retaliate against quintessential American goods like Kentucky bourbon, bluejeans and Harley-Davidson motorcycles.

articles.headline: Stung by U.S. Tariff Plan, Canada Takes a Deep Breath
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, conscious of how much his country’s economy relies on the United States, remained calm and firm.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, conscious of how much his country’s economy relies on the United States, remained calm and firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — It was yet another slap in the face from the bellicose best friend and neighbor to the south.
articles.byline: By Catherine Porter and Ian Austen

articles.headline: Condé Nast’s 26-Year-Old Man of the Moment
articles.snippet: Is Phillip Picardi, a former intern who now heads up Teen Vogue, the future of Condé Nast? Anna Wintour seems to think so.
articles.abstract: Is Phillip Picardi, a former intern who now heads up Teen Vogue, the future of Condé Nast? Anna Wintour seems to think so.
articles.lead_paragraph: Within 20 minutes of our interview, I knew a lot about Phillip Picardi. He is, for example, an Aries with a Leo rising and a Sagittarius moon. When he was in elementary school, he didn’t smile for three years because he was “so inspired by Victoria Beckham and Posh Spice.” In his teenage years, the background of his MySpace page was a “giant collage of shirtless dudes.”

articles.headline: The Little Movie Studio That Could
articles.snippet: How three young upstarts from the New York indie film scene built A24 into a Hollywood powerhouse.
articles.abstract: How three young upstarts from the New York indie film scene built A24 into a Hollywood powerhouse.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — At the Sundance Film Festival here in January, executives at A24, the upstart movie and television studio, stood in the back of a makeshift theater looking as if they were about to be physically ill.

articles.headline: Once Banned, Now Loved and Loathed: How the AR-15 Became ‘America’s Rifle’
articles.snippet: The AR-15 cemented its place in American culture after the assault weapons ban ended, at a time of heightened interest in the military, and as shooting was popularized in video game culture.
articles.abstract: The AR-15 cemented its place in American culture after the assault weapons ban ended, at a time of heightened interest in the military, and as shooting was popularized in video game culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Swarey bought his AR-15 rifle five years ago after shooting guns in video games. Jessie K. Fletcher, a former Marine sniper, was given one by his platoon after he stepped on a bomb in Afghanistan that blew off his legs. Jessica Dorantes, a Texas police officer, will not go on patrol without hers.
articles.byline: By Ali Watkins, John Ismay and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: Trump’s Tariff Plan Leaves Blue-Collar Winners and Losers
articles.snippet: Tariffs would help steel and aluminum makers that President Trump championed. But manufacturers using their products may be in for harder times.
articles.abstract: Tariffs would help steel and aluminum makers that President Trump championed. But manufacturers using their products may be in for harder times.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s announcement that he planned to impose steep tariffs on imported steel and aluminum delighted some blue-collar industries he had championed. “Enthusiastic and gratified are probably understatements,” said Michael A. Bless, the president of Century Aluminum.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Thugs, Leeches, Shouting and Shoving at Trump Hotel in Panama
articles.snippet: The new owner of the Trump International Hotel in Panama City wants the Trump brand gone. The president’s family business refuses. The standoff has not been pretty.
articles.abstract: The new owner of the Trump International Hotel in Panama City wants the Trump brand gone. The president’s family business refuses. The standoff has not been pretty.
articles.lead_paragraph: PANAMA — The Trump International Hotel and Tower here is President Trump’s only hotel property in Latin America. At 70 stories, it is the tallest building in Panama, offers sweeping views of Panama Bay and features five outdoor swimming pools. The rooms come with Trump-branded bathrobes, stationery and mouthwash.
articles.byline: By Kirk Semple, Ben Protess and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Mueller’s Focus on Adviser to Emirates Suggests Broader Investigation
articles.snippet: The special counsel has asked about the role of the adviser, George Nader, in White House policymaking, indicating that he is examining Emirati influence on the Trump administration.
articles.abstract: The special counsel has asked about the role of the adviser, George Nader, in White House policymaking, indicating that he is examining Emirati influence on the Trump administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — George Nader, a Lebanese-American businessman, has hovered on the fringes of international diplomacy for three decades. He was a back-channel negotiator with Syria during the Clinton administration, reinvented himself as an adviser to the de facto ruler of the United Arab Emirates, and last year was a frequent visitor to President Trump’s White House.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, David D. Kirkpatrick and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: As Primaries Begin, Divided Voters Weigh What It Means to Be a Democrat
articles.snippet: Primary elections in Texas on Tuesday and Illinois this month will test the growing divide in the Democratic Party between bold liberalism and tradition.
articles.abstract: Primary elections in Texas on Tuesday and Illinois this month will test the growing divide in the Democratic Party between bold liberalism and tradition.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALOS HILLS, Ill. — When Representative Daniel Lipinski, a conservative-leaning Democrat and scion of Chicago’s political machine, agreed to one joint appearance last month with his liberal primary challenger, the divide in the Democratic Party was evident in the audience that showed up.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: School Officer: A Job With Many Roles and One Big Responsibility
articles.snippet: School resource officers like the one under scrutiny following the Florida shooting are expected to act as counselors and instructors as well as the first line of defense.
articles.abstract: School resource officers like the one under scrutiny following the Florida shooting are expected to act as counselors and instructors as well as the first line of defense.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maple syrup gumming up the gun belt isn’t normally a hazard of police work. But it is a common problem for Cpl. Pamela Revels when students have been eating pancakes at the school breakfast.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul, Timothy Williams and Anemona Hartocollis

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Is Over, Says Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: About a dozen venture capitalists recently took a bus tour through the Midwest, and a funny thing happened: They caught the heartland bug.
articles.abstract: About a dozen venture capitalists recently took a bus tour through the Midwest, and a funny thing happened: They caught the heartland bug.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Oh my god, this is so cute!”

articles.headline: Virtual Currency Offerings May Hit a New Peak with Telegram Coin Sale
articles.snippet: It took Facebook seven years to raise its first $1 billion. Thanks to an initial coin offering, it could take the messaging app just four months.
articles.abstract: It took Facebook seven years to raise its first $1 billion. Thanks to an initial coin offering, it could take the messaging app just four months.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It took Facebook seven years to raise $1 billion from investors. Uber did it in five.

articles.headline: Here Come the Fake Videos, Too
articles.snippet: Artificial intelligence video tools make it relatively easy to put one person’s face on another person’s body with few traces of manipulation. I tried it on myself. What could go wrong?
articles.abstract: Artificial intelligence video tools make it relatively easy to put one person’s face on another person’s body with few traces of manipulation. I tried it on myself. What could go wrong?
articles.lead_paragraph: The scene opened on a room with a red sofa, a potted plant and the kind of bland modern art you’d see on a therapist’s wall.

articles.headline: Dorm Living for Professionals Comes to San Francisco
articles.snippet: San Francisco's middle class, including teachers, copywriters and others, are engaging in an unusual experiment in communal living. Starcity, a new developer, is creating dorm rooms expressly for them.
articles.abstract: San Francisco's middle class, including teachers, copywriters and others, are engaging in an unusual experiment in communal living. Starcity, a new developer, is creating dorm rooms expressly for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In search of reasonable rent, the middle-class backbone of San Francisco — maitre d’s, teachers, bookstore managers, lounge musicians, copywriters and merchandise planners — are engaging in an unusual experiment in communal living: They are moving into dorms.

articles.headline: Big Wall Street Banks See Chance to Weaken Post-Crisis Rule
articles.snippet: A provision in a Senate bill aimed at easing Dodd-Frank’s restrictions on smaller banks could pave the way for rollbacks for big banks, critics say.
articles.abstract: A provision in a Senate bill aimed at easing Dodd-Frank’s restrictions on smaller banks could pave the way for rollbacks for big banks, critics say.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first significant bipartisan attempt to alter rules established after the 2008 financial crisis is turning into a battle on Capitol Hill, as some of the biggest Wall Street banks seek to weaken a crucial requirement aimed at ensuring that they can withstand financial losses.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter, Kenneth P. Vogel and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: In Italy Election, Anti-E.U. Views Pay Off for Far Right and Populists
articles.snippet: There was no outright winner, but the likely result will be a government in Italy that is significantly less invested in a united Europe.
articles.abstract: There was no outright winner, but the likely result will be a government in Italy that is significantly less invested in a united Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Italians registered their dismay with the European political establishment on Sunday, handing a majority of votes in a national election to hard-right and populist forces that ran a campaign fueled by anti-immigrant anger.

articles.headline: Ben Carson of HUD on His Vexing Reign: Brain Surgery Was Easier Than This
articles.snippet: Mr. Carson has been whipsawed by a job he has found puzzling, with his goals undermined by his indecisiveness, his staffing mistakes and a president indifferent to his department’s mission.
articles.abstract: Mr. Carson has been whipsawed by a job he has found puzzling, with his goals undermined by his indecisiveness, his staffing mistakes and a president indifferent to his department’s mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before Ben Carson accepted President Trump’s offer to become secretary of housing and urban development, a friend implored him to turn down the job to preserve the reputation he had earned as a brilliant neurosurgeon and lost, in part, as a politician.

articles.headline: Trump Administration Stalls Largest Tech Merger in New Sign of Protectionism
articles.snippet: U.S. regulators intervened in a possible purchase of the chip maker Qualcomm by an Asian company, Broadcom. It was a rare public intervention in a pending deal.
articles.abstract: U.S. regulators intervened in a possible purchase of the chip maker Qualcomm by an Asian company, Broadcom. It was a rare public intervention in a pending deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: A possible merger of two giant makers of computer chips could revolutionize the all-important industry — which touches everything from smartphones to cars — and shift the balance of power from California to Asia.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport, Cecilia Kang and Chad Bray
